datafield.subfield: Commentary on the Organon ; Compendium of Moral Philosophy and Commentary on Aristotle's Moral Philosophy (Nichomachean Ethics).

Edward Burgess, from Reginald Atkinson, London, April 1920. Inscription on Flyleaf: "Cita Sagitta fid(e)l(e),(...) tibi (...) amor arcus, sityZ tibi Calui, pu(.)ta, SropusgZ divs" [an arrow set in motion (is) true (...) for you (...) love of the bow. The selection (autograph) I have kindled for you, consider, (...ibus) divine.]
Item cataloged from existing description by C. Pierce and J. Fox, and in hand by Erika Milo and Ian Scott, July/August 2018.
All requests for permission to quote or publish from manuscripts must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections & University Archives.

Scholastic philosophy is at first influenced by Platonism through the mediation of St. Augustine from the 13th Century... by Aristotle's philosophy... The Stagirite became the official philosopher... Toward the middle of the fifteenth century [scholasticism] succumbs to the secular and liberal reaction inaugurated by the Renaissance." Weber's History of Philosophy, pp. 202, 239. The Organon, or instrument of philosophy was earnestly studied before and after the dominance of Aristotelian metaphysics under scholasticism. Aristotle is "the real founder of logic," and his system of deductive logic, in the opinion of Weber, "constitutes his... claim to fame."

Collation: Quarto (228 x 175 mm) in quires of 8 (except vii^4, viii^2, xi^6, xv-xvii^6, xviii^10, xix^6, xxiii^6, xxiv^10, xxv-vi^6, xxv-vi^6, xxviii^4, xxxv^1, xxxvii^4, xli-ii^4, xlvi^10)(to compliment these exceptions ff. 171-172, ff. 187-188, f245 had been removed before writing). No rubrication; no signatures. Catchwords only before missing pages. Four sets of numeration, to reflect the four books in this volume.
Layout: 32-42 4 mm lines in a single column, upon a writing area of 145 x 110 mm. With much variety to number of lines due to boldly emphasized initial words of each section. No visible ruling.
Script: Humanistic cursive in a single hand.
Decoration: Line diagrams in same black ink on f21v (Diagram describing the rules of argument oppositions) & f32r (Matrix concerning the methods of forming an arguement).

Binding: Vellum over boards 235 x 176 mm, showing 3 raised bands labelled "Aristotles XVe siede MSS." With page edges dressed en rouge. Attempted binding repair with at least 4 bands of reused parchment, with text, strapped between interior board and spine.

Notes: [Books I, II, III] I. (f1r) page 1, Organi Logici Praefatio; p. 60, de Argumentatione. p. 93, de Speciebus sy[logis]mi.; p. 101, finis; Compendii Logici Charts on p. 46, p. 67, pp 69-74, p.84; II. (f52r) p.1 In Universam ar[ticu]lis Philosophiam Com[m]entarii; p.2 De Nomine et existentia philosophiae/ About the Name and existence of philosophiae; p.23 Prolegomena Logicae/ A primer of logic; p.90 In Introductionem Porphirii/ In introduction to Porphiry; p.97 Quomodo Probent Perpatetici Platonem Idaeas Externas Cogitasse / In what way the Aristotelians prove Plato Have been thought external ideas; p.296 In Librum Catagoriarum Aristotelis disputationes...; p.319 de Priori Analisi; p.329 de Posteriori Analisi; p.365 In Libros Topirorum; p.382 Totius Logicae Finis; IIIa (f.247r) p.1 Moralis Phi(losophi)ae Compendium IIIb. (f.255) p.1 In Moralem Philosophiam Aristotoles; p.11 In decem libros eticorum; p.46 de Principiis Actionis; p.66 de Actibus Humanis; p.88 de Passionibus Animi; pp. 105-132 de Virtutibus.
Shelfmark: Eugene, OR, Special Collections and University Archives, University of Oregon, MS 037.
